Name: Reporting on employment turnover of city employees during the COVID-19 emergency, and providing for the repeal of such requirement upon the expiration thereof.
Title: A Local Law in relation to reporting on employment turnover of city employees during the COVID-19 emergency, and providing for the repeal of such requirement upon the expiration thereof

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations

Summary: This bill would require the Department of Citywide Administrative Services (DCAS) to submit a report to the Mayor and the Speaker of the Council on city workers whose employment was terminated during the COVID-19 pandemic. The information required to be reported would include the total number of employees at each agency whose employment was voluntarily or involuntarily terminated, by EEO-4 job group and reason for termination. DCAS would be required to report such information covering the three years before the COVID-19 pandemic began and through the three years after the pandemic ends.

\pard\ltrpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\qj Section 1. Definitions. As used in this local law, the following terms have the following meanings:\par
Agency. The term \ldblquote agency\rdblquote  has the same meaning ascribed to such term in section 1150 of the New York city charter and shall include the offices of the borough presidents, the comptroller and the public advocate.\par
COVID-19. The term \ldblquote COVID-19\rdblquote  means the 2019 novel coronavirus or 2019-nCoV.\par
COVID-19 local state of emergency. The term \ldblquote COVID-19 local state of emergency\rdblquote  means the local state of emergency declared by the mayor in executive order number 98 issued on March 12, 2020, or any executive order renewing or extending such emergency.\par
Department. The term \ldblquote department\rdblquote  means the department of citywide administrative services.\par
\'a7 2. a. No later than 4 years after the COVID-19 local state of emergency has expired, the department shall submit a report to the mayor and the speaker of the council regarding employment turnover of city employees during the COVID-19 local state of emergency. \par
b. The report required by subdivision a of this section shall include the following information: \par
1. The total number of active city employees employed by each agency 3 years before the COVID-19 local state of emergency was declared;\par
2. The total number of active city employees employed by each agency 2 years before the COVID-19 local state of emergency was declared;\par
3. The total number of active city employees employed by each agency 1 year before the COVID-19 local state of emergency was declared;\par
4. The total number of active city employees employed by each agency on the date the COVID-19 local state of emergency was declared;\par
5. The total number of city employees in each EEO-4 job group at each agency whose employment was involuntarily terminated during the 3 years before the COVID-19 local state of emergency was declared;\par
6. The total number of city employees at each agency whose employment was involuntarily terminated during the 3 years before the COVID-19 local state of emergency was declared, disaggregated by the reason for termination;\par
7. The total number of city employees in each EEO-4 job group at each agency whose employment was voluntarily terminated by the employee during the 3 years before the COVID-19 local state of emergency was declared;\par
8. The total number of city employees at each agency whose employment was voluntarily terminated by the employee during the 3 years before the COVID-19 local state of emergency was declared, disaggregated by the reason for termination, if such information is available;\par
9. The total number of city employees who were transferred to another agency during the 3 years before the COVID-19 local state of emergency was declared;\par
10. The total number of active city employees employed by each agency during the pendency of the COVID-19 local state of emergency;\par
11. The total number of city employees in each EEO-4 job group at each agency whose employment was involuntarily terminated during the pendency of the COVID-19 local state of emergency;\par
12. The total number of city employees at each agency whose employment was involuntarily terminated during the pendency of the COVID-19 local state of emergency, disaggregated by the reason for termination;\par
13. The total number of city employees in each EEO-4 job group at each agency whose employment was voluntarily terminated by the employee during the pendency of the COVID-19 local state of emergency;\par
14. The total number of city employees at each agency whose employment was voluntarily terminated by the employee during the pendency of the COVID-19 local state of emergency, disaggregated by the reason for termination, if such information is available;\par
15. The total number of city employees who were transferred to another agency during the pendency of the COVID-19 local state of emergency;\par
16. The total number of active city employees employed by each agency on the date the COVID-19 local state of emergency expired;\par
17. The total number of active city employees employed by each agency 1 year after the COVID-19 local state of emergency expired;\par
18. The total number of active city employees employed by each agency 2 years after the COVID-19 local state of emergency expired;\par
19. The total number of active city employees employed by each agency 3 years after the COVID-19 local state of emergency expired;\par
20. The total number of city employees in each EEO-4 job group at each agency whose employment was involuntarily terminated during the 3 years after the COVID-19 local state of emergency expired;\par
21. The total number of city employees at each agency whose employment was involuntarily terminated during the 3 years after the COVID-19 local state of emergency expired, disaggregated by the reason for termination;\par
22. The total number of city employees in each EEO-4 job group at each agency whose employment was voluntarily terminated by the employee during the 3 years after the COVID-19 local state of emergency expired; \par
23. The total number of city employees at each agency whose employment was voluntarily terminated by the employee during the 3 years after the COVID-19 local state of emergency expired, disaggregated by the reason for termination, if such information is available; and \par
24. The total number of city employees who were transferred to another agency during the 3 years after the COVID-19 local state of emergency expired.\par
\'a7 3. The department shall include in the report required by section two of this local law recommendations for policies that could be implemented by agencies to retain city employees.\par
\'a7 4. All agencies shall cooperate with the department as may be necessary and proper to ensure compliance with this local law. The department may request from any agency, including the office of payroll administration and financial information services agency, information it deems necessary to enable it to properly carry out its function.\par
\'a7 5. The report required by section two of this local law shall not include any personally identifiable information.\par
\'a7 6. This local law takes effect immediately and expires and is deemed repealed upon submission of the report required by section two of this local law.\ul\par
